questions.text: On pre-operative assessment of a patient posted for a bariatric surgery, during airway examination, the following picture was seen. Which score for assessment of airway can be predicted from this?
questions.solution:
• Mallampati classification is a frequently performed test that examines the size of the tongue in relation to the oral cavity. The more the tongue obstructs the view of the pharyngeal structures, the more difficult intubation may be.
    • Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
    • Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
    • Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
    • Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.
  • POGO score and Cormack Lehane score are scores used to denote the visibility of larynx during direct laryngoscopy.
  • Wilson score combines weight, head and neck movement, jaw movement, receding mandible and buck teeth to give a score predicting the ease of laryngoscopy.

Key takeaway:

Mallampati score:

  1. Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
  2. Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
  3. Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
  4. Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

questions.text:
Match the correct number with the parts of the cuff system of an endotracheal tube
a. Inflation valve
b. Pilot balloon
c. Inflation lumen
d. Inflation tube
e. Cuff
questions.solution:
• Given image is that of an endotracheal tube and the labels are those of the cuff system of a tube.
  • A cuff system consists of the cuff plus an inflation system, which includes an inflation tube, a pilot balloon, and an inflation valve.
  • An inflation lumen in the tube wall may also be present.
  • The purpose of the cuff system is to provide a seal between the tube and tracheal wall to prevent passage of pharyngeal contents into the trachea and ensure that no gas leaks past the cuff during positive pressure ventilation.
  • The cuff also serves to center the tube in the trachea.

Key takeaway: A cuff system consists of the cuff plus an inflation system, which includes an inflation tube, a pilot balloon, and an inflation valve.

Tags:

Topic: Airway Management

Difficulty level: Moderate

References: Understanding Anaesthesia Equipment (Jerry A. Dorsch, Susan E. Dorsch) 5th edition Page number:574.

choices.text: Administer a dose of muscle relaxant to the patient
Inflate the endotracheal tube cuff a little more

questions.text: A patient who is undergoing a laparoscopy surgery under general anaesthesia has the given trace on capnography. What will be your next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
• The simplest and most widely used form of display for exhaled CO2 is the time capnogram.
  • The above time capnograph shows the presence of clefts (curare clefts) during phase III indicating spontaneous breathing efforts during controlled mechanical ventilation.
  • Hence it warrants administration of muscle relaxant to the patient.

Key takeaway: Curare clefts during mechanical ventilation on controlled modes on the time capnograph indicate that the patient is making efforts to breath.

Tags:

Topic:Monitoring

Difficulty level: Easy

References: Miller's Anesthesia, 10th Edition, Chapter 37 Respiratory Monitoring, page number:1168

choices.text: Excision of a lipoma at the arm level

questions.text: Blocking the brachial plexus at the level showing the following image on the ultrasound will not allow which of the following surgeries to be performed?
questions.solution:
• Given image shows the sonoanatomy of the brachial plexus at the level of the interscalene approach to block it.
  • An interscalene brachial plexus block is indicated for procedures involving the shoulder and upper arm. (Option A,B,C,)
  • Roots C5 to C7 are most densely blocked with this approach, and the ulnar nerve originating from C8 and T1 is usually spared.
  • Therefore, interscalene blocks are not appropriate for surgery at or distal to the elbow. (Option D)
  • For complete surgical anesthesia of the shoulder as well as postoperative analgesia following clavicle surgical reduction and fixation, the supraclavicular nerve (cutaneous branch of C3 and C4) may need to be supplemented with a cervical plexus block.
  • After identification of the sternocleidomastoid muscle and interscalene groove at the approximate level of C6, a high-frequency linear transducer is placed perpendicular to the course of the interscalene muscles.
  • The brachial plexus and anterior and middle scalene muscles should be visualized in cross-section. The brachial plexus at this level appears most commonly as three hypoechoic circles with hyperechoic borders.
  • These circles generally correspond to either nerve roots of C5, C6, and C7; C5 and two rootlets of C6 (C6 A and B); or, rarely, the upper, middle, and lower trunks.
  • As the interscalene block is used for shoulder analgesia, the primary target for local anesthetic should be between the two most superficial nerves (most commonly C5 and C6). The carotid artery and internal jugular vein may be seen lying anterior to the anterior scalene muscle; the sternocleidomastoid is visible superficially as it tapers to form its posterior edge

  • Contraindications to an interscalene block include local infection, severe coagulopathy, local anesthetic allergy, and patient refusal.
  • A properly performed interscalene block almost invariably blocks the ipsilateral phrenic nerve (completely with nerve stimulation techniques, but less so with certain low-volume ultrasound guided techniques), so careful consideration must be given to patients with severe pulmonary disease or preexisting contralateral phrenic nerve palsy.
  • Bilateral interscalene blocks are absolutely contraindicated. Hemidiaphragmatic paresis may result in dyspnea, hypercapnia, and hypoxemia.
  • Horner syndrome (myosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis) frequently results from proximal tracking of local anesthetic and blockade of sympathetic fibers to the cervicothoracic ganglion.
  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve involvement often induces hoarseness. In a patient with contralateral vocal cord paralysis, respiratory distress may ensue.
  • Other site-specific risks include vertebral artery injection (suspect if immediate seizure activity is observed), spinal or epidural injection, and pneumothorax; however, these complications have primarily been reported with non-ultrasound-guided blocks.
  • As little as 1 mL of local anesthetic delivered into the vertebral artery may induce a seizure.
  • Similarly, intrathecal, subdural, and epidural local anesthetic spread is possible; and injection into the spinal cord resulting in a cervical syrinx has been reported.
  • Lastly, pneumothorax is possible because of the close proximity of the apical pleura.

Key takeaway:

An interscalene brachial plexus block is indicated for procedures involving the shoulder and upper arm. Roots C5 to C7 are most densely blocked with this approach, and the ulnar nerve originating from C8 and T1 is usually spared. Therefore, interscalene blocks are not appropriate for surgery at or distal to the elbow.

Tags:

Topic: Regional Anaesthesia

Difficulty level: Moderate

References: Morgan and Mikhail's Clinical Anaesthesiology 7th Edition, Chapter 46 Peripheral Nerve Blocks, page number. 1017-1018

choices.text: Post tetanic count of >15 is equivalent to two twitches in TOF
Post tetanic count >5 indicates profound neuromuscular blockade
Post tetanic potentiation is seen in the presence of non depolarising agent
Red box is known as post tetanic potentiation

questions.text: All of the following are true about the given image except
questions.solution:
Intense muscle blockade can completely abolish the response to a train of four.

  1. Tetanic stimulation increases the mobilisation of ACh in the presynaptic membrane.
  2. Subsequent electrical stimulation uses twitches at 1-second intervals, releasing supranormal concentrations of ACh sufficient to overcome the effect of non-depolarising relaxants. This is called POST TETANIC POTENTIATION. (Option D)

Option B: PTC < 5 indicates profound neuromuscular blockade.

Option A: A PTC > 15 is at least equivalent to two twitches of a TOF, and at this level, successful pharmacological reversal of the remaining muscle blockade is possible.

Option C: Post tetanic potentiation is seen in presence of non depolarising agent and phase II block with succinylcholine.

Key takeaway: PTC < 5 indicates profound neuromuscular blockade.

Tags:

Topic: Monitoring

Difficulty level: Moderate

References: Fundamentals of anaesthesia 4th edition, Ted Lin, Tim Smith and Colin Pinnock, chapter 45, page number:883.

choices.text: Chest x-ray is to be taken after a forceful expiration
Initiating mechanical ventilation will resolve the symptoms
It is less common with internal jugular vein cannulation
Chest drain insertion will resolve the symptoms

questions.text: A patient involved in a road traffic accident comes to the hospital with an open fracture of the humerus with blood loss and hemorrhagic shock. Immediately fluid resuscitation is started and subclavian vein is cannulated. Patient develops breathlessness and desaturates. Which of the following statements is false regarding the complication shown in the given chest x ray?
questions.solution:
Given image shows the presence of a pneumothorax which is presumably due to a complication during insertion of the subclavian vein catheter.

Pneumothorax is an infrequent event during central venous cannulation, and most cases are associated with subclavian vein cannulation. (Option C)

When pneumothorax is suspected, the chest x-ray should be obtained in the upright position and after a forced exhalation (if possible). The forced exhalation will decrease lung volume but will not decrease the volume of air in a pneumothorax; the result is an increase in the relative size of the pneumothorax on the chest x-ray, which can facilitate detection. (Option A)

Initiating positive pressure ventilation is detrimental to patients with a pneumothorax as it can worsen the pneumothorax if not drained by a chest tube and can lead to tension pneumothorax. Chest tube placement should be done immediately and is the first line of management in pneumothorax.(Option D)

Key takeaway:

Initiating positive pressure ventilation is detrimental to patients with a pneumothorax as it can worsen the pneumothorax if not drained by a chest tube and can lead to tension pneumothorax.

Tags:

Topic: Critical care

Difficulty level: Moderate

References: Marino's The ICU Book (Paul Marino), 4th Edition, chapter 2, page number:30.

questions.text: Image shows lines corresponding to the iliac crests that are palpated while giving spinal anaesthesia. The line connecting the highest points of the two iliac crests is called the tuffier's line. Tuffier's line passes through _______ vertebral body
questions.solution:
During positioning for spinal or epidural anaesthesia, a patient is positioned in the given manner.

Spinous processes are usually palpable and help to define the midline.

A line drawn between the highest points of both iliac crests (Tuffier's line) usually crosses either the body of L4 or the L4-L5 inter- space. Counting spinous processes up or down from these reference points identifies other spinal levels.

Key takeaway: Tuffier's line passes through the body of L4 vertebra or the L4-L5 inter-space

Tags:

Topic: Regional Anesthesia

Difficulty level: Easy

References: Morgan and Mikhail's Clinical Anaesthesiology, 7th Edition, Chapter 45, page number:. 981

questions.text: All of the following can be techniques for performing the given procedure except
questions.solution:
Given image is that of locating epidural space.

  • Two techniques make it possible to determine when the tip of the needle has entered the (potential) epidural space: the 'loss of resistance' and 'hanging drop' The loss of resistance technique is preferred by most clinicians.
  • The needle is advanced through the subcutaneous tissues with the stylet in place until the interspinous ligament is entered, as noted by an increase in tissue resistance. The stylet or introducer is removed, and a glass syringe is filled with saline or air is attached to the hub of the needle.
  • If the tip of the needle is within the ligament, gentle attempts at injection are met with resistance, and injection is not possible. The needle is then slowly advanced, millimeter by millimeter, with either continuous or rapidly repeating attempts at injection.
  • As the tip of the needle just enters the epidural space, there is a sudden loss of resistance, and injection is now easy. Once the interspinous ligament has been entered and the stylet has been removed, the hanging drop technique requires that the hub of the needle be filled with solution so that a drop hangs from its outside opening.
  • The needle is then slowly advanced deeper. As long as the tip of the needle remains within the ligamentous structures, the drop remains However, as the tip of the needle enters the epidural space, it creates negative pressure, and the drop of fluid is sucked into the needle. If the needle becomes plugged, the drop will not be drawn into the hub of the needle, and accidental dural puncture may occur. Some clinicians prefer to use this technique for the paramedian approach and for cervical epidurals.
  • Experienced 'epiduralists' will generally have sensed the 'give' in their hands as the epidural needle tip passes through the ligamentum flavum, and rely on either the loss of resistance or hanging drop as confirmation (rather than as the primary test) that the needle has entered the epidural space.

Key takeaway: Loss of resistance to air, saline and hanging drop technique are the techniques of locating epidural space.

Tags:

Topic: Regional Anaesthesia

Difficulty level: Easy

choices.text: They are installed at ground levels for ready access
Liquid must be kept above its boiling point
They must be far away from sidewalks and parked vehicles
They should be located where exposure to potential ignition source is minimal

questions.text: In your hospital campus, you come across the following structure. Identify the incorrect statement about it from among the following.
questions.solution:
Given image shows a liquid oxygen storage tank.

  • Liquid oxygen containers are installed at ground level so that they are readily accessible to supply trucks. (option A)
  • To prevent the liquid from evaporating, it must be kept at or below its boiling point (-297°F)by keeping it in special insulated vessels. (Option B)
  • The containers should be located where exposure to potential ignition sources is minimal. NFPA standards specify how far the container must be from sidewalks, parked vehicles, and other objects. (Option C and D)

Key takeaway: In a liquid oxygen storage tank, to prevent the liquid from evaporating, it must be kept at or below its boiling point (-297°F)by keeping it in special insulated vessels.

Tags:

Topic: Oxygen therapy

Difficulty level: Easy

References: Understanding Anesthetic Equipment & Procedures, Dwarkadas K Baheti Chapter 4 Medical Gas Supply, Storage, and Safety, page number. 47-48.

choices.text: Can deliver high tidal volumes if activated in inspiration

questions.text: All of the following are the advantages of the given part of the anaesthesia machine except:
questions.solution:
Given image is that of the oxygen flush.

The oxygen flush (oxygen bypass, emergency oxygen bypass) receives oxygen from the pipeline inlet or cylinder pressure regulator and directs a high unmetered flow directly to the common gas outlet. It is commonly labeled 'O2+'.

  • It is a self closing device, operable with one hand, and designed to minimise unintentional activation. (option A and B)
  • Oxygen flush activation during inspiration delivered by the anesthesia ventilator will result in delivery of high tidal volumes and possible barotrauma.

Key takeaway: Oxygen flush activation during inspiration delivered by the anesthesia ventilator will result in delivery of high tidal volumes and possible barotrauma.

Tags:

Topic: Anesthesia Machine

Difficulty level: Easy

References: Understanding Anaesthesia Equipment (Jerry A. Dorsch, Susan E. Dorsch) 5th edition Page number:101.

questions.text: What size is the IV cannula shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a pink cannula which is 20G in size.


Reference: Equipment in Anesthesia and Critical care, 2014 edition, Page number. 264

questions.text: The image of a Pro-Seal LMA is given below. Above what site is the marked area of the airway positioned?
questions.solution:
• The internal gastric tube (drainage tube), which is kept immediately above the esophageal aperture to aspirate GI fluids, is indicated by the arrow.
  • A reusable supraglottic airway device called the LMA ProSeal™ includes a gastric drainage tube that is positioned lateral to the main airway tube and terminates at the tip of the mask.
  • By separating the gastrointestinal and respiratory tracts, the gastric drainage tube allows regurgitated fluid to flow up the drain tube and bypass the glottis, shielding the airway from contamination in the event of passive regurgitation.

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page number:1389-1392.

questions.text: All of the following are complications associated with the use of the following airway device except
questions.solution:
Given image is that of an oropharyngeal airway being inserted.

Option a: Facial, neck, or tongue edema, either unilateral or bi-lateral, can occur following surgery, especially in the sitting position, and can result in airway obstruction following use of an oral airway.

Option b: Uvular edema possibly caused by the uvula becoming entrapped between the hard palate and an oropharyngeal airway has been reported.

Option c: Part or all of an airway may become displaced into the pharynx, tracheobronchial tree, or esophagus.

Topic: Airway Management

Difficulty level: easy

Reference: Understanding Anaesthesia Equipment ( Jerry A. Dorsch, Susan E. Dorsch) 5th edition page number:457.

choices.text: Do not function at high fresh gas flows
Exhaled moisture can cause valve sticking
Venting exhaled gas into atmosphere can cause contamination

questions.text: All of the following are the disadvantages of the given instrument except:
questions.solution:
1. Resuscitation bags (AMBU bags or bag-mask units) are commonly used for emergency ventilation because of their simplicity, portability, and ability to deliver almost 100% oxygen
  2. Bag-mask ventilation maintains higher oxygen saturations during tracheal intubation in critically ill adult patients.
  3. High concentrations of oxygen can be delivered to a mask or tracheal tube during spontaneous or controlled ventilation if a source of high fresh gas flow is connected to the inlet nipple.
  4. The patient valve opens during controlled or spontaneous inspiration to allow gas flow from the ventilation bag to the patient.
  5. Rebreathing is prevented by venting exhaled gas to the atmosphere through exhalation ports in this valve.
  6. The compressible, self-refilling ventilation bag also contains an intake valve. This valve closes during bag compression, permitting positive-pressure ventilation. The bag is refilled by flow through the fresh gas inlet and across the intake valve.
  7. Connecting a reservoir to the intake valve helps prevent the entrainment of room air. The reservoir valve assembly is really two unidirectional valves: the inlet valve and the outlet valve. The inlet valve allows ambient air to enter the ventilation bag if fresh gas flow is inadequate to maintain reservoir filling.
  8. Positive pressure in the reservoir bag opens the outlet valve, which vents oxygen if fresh gas flow is excessive.
  9. There are several disadvantages to resuscitator breathing systems.
  10. First, they require high fresh gas flows to achieve a high Fio2. Fio2 is directly proportional to the oxygen concentration and flow rate of the gas mixture supplied to the resuscitator (usually 100% oxygen) and inversely proportional to the minute ventilation delivered to the patient.
  11. Although a normally functioning patient valve has low resistance to inspiration and expiration, exhaled moisture can cause valve sticking.
  12. Finally, venting exhaled gas into the atmosphere can lead to local contamination if the expiratory gases are contaminated with infectious agents.

Topic: airway management

Difficulty level: difficult

Reference: Morgan and Mikhail's Clinical Anaesthesiology 7th Edition, chapter 3, page number:334.

questions.text: The given inhalational agent is the agent of choice for induction by inhalation because:
questions.solution:
• Sevoflurane is the agent of choice for inhalational induction due to its pleasant sweet odor, which prevents airway irritation, making it well-tolerated in children and adults.
  • Non-pungent, thus preferred for patients where smooth and rapid induction is essential, especially in pediatric anesthesia.
  • Low blood-gas solubility (λb/g 0.65) allows for rapid onset and recovery compared to agents like isoflurane.
  • Induction can be achieved within 1 minute using 4-8% sevoflurane in a 50% nitrous oxide/oxygen mixture.
  • Stable vapor pressure, allowing its use in conventional vaporizers without the need for specialized equipment.
  • Sevoflurane is the least metabolized of all volatile anesthetics, with about 5% metabolized by the liver, making it relatively safe.
  • Sevoflurane has minimal effects on the cardiovascular system, preserving heart rate and blood pressure, making it suitable for a wide range of patients.
  • Its non-irritating properties also make it useful in cases where airway reactivity is a concern, such as patients with asthma or COPD.

Why not others:

  • Low MAC requirement: Sevoflurane has a moderate MAC (2.1%), but its main advantage is its rapid induction and emergence, not just its MAC.
  • Reduction of bronchial secretion: While it doesn't irritate the airway, the sweet odor and non-pungency are key for induction.
  • Temperature compensated: Although stability is a benefit, it's not the primary reason for its preference in induction.

Key Takeaways:

  • Sevoflurane is the preferred agent for smooth and rapid inhalation induction due to its sweet odor, non-pungency, and rapid onset/recovery. It's safe for both pediatric and adult patients, with minimal airway irritation, making it highly versatile.

Tags : inicet nov 2020

Reference: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anaesthesiology, edition 6, chapter8, page number:168.
